Events are held in the events space at the back of the store. A 20% discount is offered on event related books on the day of the event. Click on the listing in the calendar for additional information, and check this site for up-to-date information on upcoming events. If you are interested in scheduling an event please contact us.                                                                                          << September        November >> Children 11:30am                             30           Story Time for Children with Irene Brodsky 11:30am           31           Literary NY Halloween Party                                                                                                                                                                                              Wednesday Oct. 5th 6:30 - 8pm           SCPS Writing Workshop with Karol Nielsen          Memoir: The Essentials          Karol Nielsen is the author of the memoir Black Elephants (October, 2011), excerpts from which have been selected as Notable Essays in The Best American Essays . She has contributed nonfiction and poetry to Smith Magazine 's The Moment anthology and many publications. Karol’s poetry collection was a finalist for the Colorado Prize for Poetry. She has taught “Writing Your Memoir” and the “Memoir Writing One-Day Workshop” at NYU-SCPS.         The Department of Humanities, Arts, and Writing at NYU’s School of Continuing and Professional Studies invites all new and experienced writers to another series of free creative writing classes at the NYU Bookstore.                                                              Thursday, Oct. 6th 11am - 12pm           Jump Start Read for The Record 2011: A Reading of Llama Llama Red Pajama with Elisha DeMaria                  Join us, and the millions of record-breakers everywhere, as together we set a new world record for the most people reading the same book on the same day and – in the process – draw attention to the importance of reading in helping a child develop the habits that ensure a lifetime of learning and success.                                                                          Thursday, Oct. 6th 2pm - 5pm          Jorge Castañeda and Robert Pastor with Eduardo Porter          Presentation of " Mañana Forever, Mexico and the Mexicans ," and " The North American Idea, A Vision of a Continental Future ".                                                                      Jorge Castañeda is the Global Distinguished Professor of Politics and Latin American and Caribbean Studies at New York University. He served as Foreign Minister of Mexico from 2000-2003 and is a regular columnist for Reforma, El País, and Time magazine.            Robert Pastor is Professor of International Relations and Director of the Center for North American Studies at American University. His long career in public service includes serving as National Security Advisor for Latin America from 1977-1981.            During this event, Dr. Castañeda will present his book Mañana Forever, Mexico and the Mexicans, and Dr. Pastor will present on his book "The North American Idea, A Vision of a Continental Future." A discussion of the books will follow, moderated by Eduardo Porter of the New York Times . Books will be available for signing and purchase.                                                           Co-sponsored by the Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies at NYU                                                                    Thursday, Oct. 6th 6pm - 7pm           Matt Mogk           Author of Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Zombies                   The most comprehensive zombie handbook ever published. In one indispensable volume, Matt Mogk busts popular myths and answers all your raging questions about the living dead. With foreword written by Max Brooks.                                                              Wednesday, Oct. 12th 5pm - 6:30pm           The Revealer Reading Series: Peter Bebergal           Author of Too Much to Dream: A Psychedelic American Boyhood with response by Ron Hogan                 Bebergal is co-author of The Faith Between Us . He studied religion at Brandeis and Harvard Divinity School and writes frequently on the intersection of popular culture, religion, and science as well as reviews on science fiction and fantasy.           Too Much to Dream places the story of a young man’s drug addiction inside the larger history of psychedelics, the American spiritual quest, and popular culture. Bebergal’s story gives a personal face to the examination of our history, offering a radical vision regarding the complex relationship between drug addiction, popular culture, and the religious experience .          Ron Hogan is the founder of Beatrice.com           Co-sponsored by The NYU Center for Religion & Media and the Revealer.                                                                         Thursday, Oct. 13th 6:30pm - 8pm          Kim Harrison         Author of the Hollows series          To survive among vampires, witches, Weres, gargoyles, trolls, fairies, and banshees—to say nothing of demons—humanity needs a guide...                   In celebration of NY Comic-Con                                              Friday, Oct. 14th 7pm - 8:30pm          Leslie Simon & singer/songwriter Jenny Owen Youngs         Author of Geek Girls Unite: How Fangirls, Bookworms, Indie Chicks, and Other Misfits Are Taking Over the World          Geek Girls Unite is a call to arms for every girl who has ever obsessed over music, comics, film, comedy, books, crafts, fashion, or anything else under the Death Star. Music geek girl Leslie Simon offers an overview of the geek elite by covering groundbreaking women, hall-of-famers, ultimate love matches, and potential frenemies, along with her top picks for playlists, books, movies, and websites.          In celebration of NY Comic-Con                                              Tuesday, Oct. 18th 6:30pm - 8pm          SCPS Inside Oustide with Charles Simic           Charles Simic has published more than sixty books, including The World Doesn't End: Prose Poems, for which he received the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry. He has also published many translations of French, Serbian, Croatian, Macedonian, and Slovenian poetry, and four books of essays. His many awards include fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, the MacArthur Foundation, and the National Endowment for the Arts. He is Professor of English at the University of New Hampshire. He is Professor of English at the University of New Hampshire, and Poet-In -Residence at the Lillian Vernon Creative Writing Program at NYU.                   Co Sponsored by -- McGhee Division of SCPS at NYU                                                                       Wednesday, Oct. 19th 5pm - 6:30pm          The Revealer Reading Series: Omri Elisha          Author of Moral Ambition: Mobilization and Social Outreach in Evangelical Megachurches , with response by Elizabeth Castelli          Omri Elisha (Queens College) will read from his new book. With response by Elizabeth Castelli (Barnard).          In this evocative ethnography, Omri Elisha examines the hopes, frustrations, and activist strategies of American evangelical Christians as they engage socially with local communities. Focusing on two Tennessee megachurches, Moral Ambition reaches beyond political controversies over issues such as abortion, same-sex marriage, and public prayer to highlight the ways that evangelicals at the grassroots of the Christian Right promote faith-based causes intended to improve the state of social welfare. The book shows how these ministries both help churchgoers embody religious virtues and create provocative new opportunities for evangelism on a public scale.          Co-sponsored by The NYU Center for Religion & Media and the Revealer. Co-sponsored by the Department of Anthropology at NYU and The Nation Institute..                                                                Thursday, Oct. 20th 12pm - 2pm          All Things Apple @ NYU - Apple Presentation          Introducing the "lunch and learn" sessions with NYU and Apple! Come for a free session and learn all about the new features for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch. Learn about Apple's new personal assistant Siri. Learn how to incorporate these services into your class and personal life, and be more productive and connected. Bring your lunch, relax and learn!                                                         Monday, Oct. 24th 6:30 - 8pm          Elizabeth Swados          Author of Waiting: Selected Nonfiction                  In WAITING, Elizabeth Swados brings her lively autobiographical pieces—many of which first ran in The New York Times and O, The Oprah Magazine —together for the first time. Among those appearing in the book are Sean Penn, Meryl Streep, Yehuda Amichai, Ellen Stewart, and Marlon Brando, as well as moving accounts of Swados's schizophrenic brother, her work with young actors from New York to Abu Dhabi, and her explorations of the creative process—all told with grace and humor.          Elizabeth Swados has published fiction, nonfiction, and children's books, and is a recipient of numerous awards.                                                    Thursday, Oct. 27th 6:30pm - 8pm          Amy Alexander          Author of Uncovering Race: A Black Journalist Story of Reporting and Reinvention                  “Amy Alexander writes with the precision of the seasoned journalist she is and the expansiveness of the wise cultural critic she has become. Her book is at once a trenchant look at the competitive world of the highest reaches of journalism and an on-the-ground narrative of the transformations in the ways we understand race, identity, and work. Her experience is unique, but her perspective is universal.”─Henry Louis Gates Jr.          Co Sponsored by -- The Nation Institute                                                            Monday, Oct. 31st 6:30 - 8:30pm          Literary New York Halloween Party         Free refreshments, surprises, signing and spooks! Come in costume!                   With many exciting surprises, including: performance by Justin Long-Moton , the youth Poet Laureate; Persia Walker , the author of Harlem Renaissance mystery novels; Famous Writers in Disguise ; and performance of New York Word Symphony of Major New York Authors.          Sponsored by the NYU Bookstore, Professor Keefer's Major New York Authors Class from the NYU McGhee Division, and The New York Literary Club at McGhee.

In celebration of NY Comic-Con                                              Friday, Oct. 14th 7pm - 8:30pm          Leslie Simon & singer/songwriter Jenny Owen Youngs         Author of Geek Girls Unite: How Fangirls, Bookworms, Indie Chicks, and Other Misfits Are Taking Over the World          Geek Girls Unite is a call to arms for every girl who has ever obsessed over music, comics, film, comedy, books, crafts, fashion, or anything else under the Death Star. Music geek girl Leslie Simon offers an overview of the geek elite by covering groundbreaking women, hall-of-famers, ultimate love matches, and potential frenemies, along with her top picks for playlists, books, movies, and websites.          In celebration of NY Comic-Con                                              Tuesday, Oct. 18th 6:30pm - 8pm          SCPS Inside Oustide with Charles Simic           Charles Simic has published more than sixty books, including The World Doesn't End: Prose Poems, for which he received the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry. He has also published many translations of French, Serbian, Croatian, Macedonian, and Slovenian poetry, and four books of essays. His many awards include fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, the MacArthur Foundation, and the National Endowment for the Arts. He is Professor of English at the University of New Hampshire. He is Professor of English at the University of New Hampshire, and Poet-In -Residence at the Lillian Vernon Creative Writing Program at NYU.                   Co Sponsored by -- McGhee Division of SCPS at NYU                                                                       Wednesday, Oct. 19th 5pm - 6:30pm          The Revealer Reading Series: Omri Elisha          Author of Moral Ambition: Mobilization and Social Outreach in Evangelical Megachurches , with response by Elizabeth Castelli          Omri Elisha (Queens College) will read from his new book. With response by Elizabeth Castelli (Barnard).          In this evocative ethnography, Omri Elisha examines the hopes, frustrations, and activist strategies of American evangelical Christians as they engage socially with local communities. Focusing on two Tennessee megachurches, Moral Ambition reaches beyond political controversies over issues such as abortion, same-sex marriage, and public prayer to highlight the ways that evangelicals at the grassroots of the Christian Right promote faith-based causes intended to improve the state of social welfare. The book shows how these ministries both help churchgoers embody religious virtues and create provocative new opportunities for evangelism on a public scale.          Co-sponsored by The NYU Center for Religion & Media and the Revealer. Co-sponsored by the Department of Anthropology at NYU and The Nation Institute..                                                                Thursday, Oct. 20th 12pm - 2pm          All Things Apple @ NYU - Apple Presentation          Introducing the "lunch and learn" sessions with NYU and Apple! Come for a free session and learn all about the new features for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch. Learn about Apple's new personal assistant Siri. Learn how to incorporate these services into your class and personal life, and be more productive and connected. Bring your lunch, relax and learn!                                                         Monday, Oct. 24th 6:30 - 8pm          Elizabeth Swados          Author of Waiting: Selected Nonfiction                  In WAITING, Elizabeth Swados brings her lively autobiographical pieces—many of which first ran in The New York Times and O, The Oprah Magazine —together for the first time. Among those appearing in the book are Sean Penn, Meryl Streep, Yehuda Amichai, Ellen Stewart, and Marlon Brando, as well as moving accounts of Swados's schizophrenic brother, her work with young actors from New York to Abu Dhabi, and her explorations of the creative process—all told with grace and humor.          Elizabeth Swados has published fiction, nonfiction, and children's books, and is a recipient of numerous awards.                                                    Thursday, Oct. 27th 6:30pm - 8pm          Amy Alexander          Author of Uncovering Race: A Black Journalist Story of Reporting and Reinvention                  “Amy Alexander writes with the precision of the seasoned journalist she is and the expansiveness of the wise cultural critic she has become. Her book is at once a trenchant look at the competitive world of the highest reaches of journalism and an on-the-ground narrative of the transformations in the ways we understand race, identity, and work. Her experience is unique, but her perspective is universal.”─Henry Louis Gates Jr.          Co Sponsored by -- The Nation Institute                                                            Monday, Oct. 31st 6:30 - 8:30pm          Literary New York Halloween Party         Free refreshments, surprises, signing and spooks! Come in costume!                   With many exciting surprises, including: performance by Justin Long-Moton , the youth Poet Laureate; Persia Walker , the author of Harlem Renaissance mystery novels; Famous Writers in Disguise ; and performance of New York Word Symphony of Major New York Authors.          Sponsored by the NYU Bookstore, Professor Keefer's Major New York Authors Class from the NYU McGhee Division, and The New York Literary Club at McGhee.
